awd_titl_txt: CC*IIE Networking Infrastructure: NWIRED - Network Innovation for Research and Education at Georgetown
awd_abstract_narration:
Georgetown University is creating a Research Community Science DMZ network for scientific collaboration internally and with external researchers, leveraging GU's extant plan for Multi-Processing Label Switching deployment on campus. The IP networks at the off-campus GU Virginia Data Center (VDC) are securely extended via encrypted Layer-2/3 connection into cloud services, including access to Amazon Web Services, Internet2 Net+, and compute and storage resources. 

These enhancements provide a friction-free, high-speed network to support Big Science and Big Data. Campus data use is expanding from terabytes to petabytes, extending into campus labs, commercial cloud services, and Mid-Atlantic Crossroads Regional Gigapop and Internet2 researchers through a layer 3 Virtual Private Cloud (VPC). The GU Science DMZ and campus MPLS network architectures securely and deterministically separate research traffic from general Internet and administrative traffic. This flexible infrastructure enables faculty and others involved in STEM to work with colleagues on campus and at off-campus sites as though they were in the same lab, leveraging the speed of the 10 Gbps connection to Internet2. The Science DMZ includes the addition of a Data Transfer Node (DTN) host to support high-speed data transfers, Software Defined Networking (SDN) to extend services beyond GU?s borders and perfSONAR to maintain performance data on network throughput, availability, and latency. The Science DMZ, with the ability to access cloud compute and storage resources, leverages 10Gbps network enhancements on campus and to Internet2,

STEM research and education are expanding at GU. Strategic investments have been and are being made in faculty, programs and infrastructure. The GU network, including the Science DMZ, enables flexible access to on campus and cloud resources, enabling more compute and storage intensive research. As research programs expand, the quality of education and research available to STEM undergraduate and graduate students is enriched.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Georgetown University created a Science DMZ that centralizes and consolidates access to network resources for GU researchers, enabling the support of science that might otherwise not be possible. The GU Science DMZ enables high-end networking, “friction free” data transfer via our regional research network, CAAREN, and Internet 2, as well as compute resources and instruments across the main and medical center campuses, to the cloud, and with colleagues and collaborators within and across disciplines, at other universities, at-large private research facilities, and National Labs. Facilitating communication between institutions with functional Science DMZs is greatly improved, increasing the ability to collaborate in a data-intensive world. 

We are creating a second science DMZ in AWS to support high-performance data transfers for researchers who need to move data in-to or out-of AWS to leverage high performance compute and storage resources.  The DTN (via Globus) and perfSONAR systems will be instantiated on EC2 servers and S3 storage to scale to the needs of researchers. 

Benefits of the on-prem/hybrid cloud architecture include: 

- Effective cost management of infrastructure support for new research exploration and validation

 - Enabling faster response and resolution of performance issues with fewer staff resources by utilizing perfSONAR, while maintaining appropriate security policies

 - Flexibility and scalability of almost unlimited compute and storage resource to meet rapidly increasing demand for data-intensive analytics and high performance computing 

- Easier data access and sharing for cross-institution collaboration when raw data is stored in the public cloud, including implementing a federated Globus system on the Data Transfer Node to enable ease of file transfer  

- Easier adaptation and integration of third-party services and software tools and quick deployment of applications 

- Streamlined single point administration and management of IT resources residing in public and private infrastructure using best-of-breed management software

To ensure the highest performance transfer speed, the Science DMZ is designed to avoid transit of the firewall at the data center and other network locations on campus.  This improves researcher’s access to high-performance applications, computing nodes, and data storage both inside Georgetown’s Data Center at Equinix-Ashburn and in the cloud (e.g., AWS and Google Cloud Platform (GCP). The on-premise Science DMZ is fully enabled for IPv6.

This award was timely. It followed a CC-NIE award that enabled GU to upgrade its campus network to 10Gbps in science/medical research buildings and to Internet2. The CC*IIE award with funding for a Science DMZ was a natural extension of this work. 

Our Science DMZ has enabled us to work to help scientists transfer large data sets. These scientists have initially included those whose work is in structural, functional and molecular brain imaging, with an early transfer of data (3TB initially) to collaborators off campus. Movement of Genomics data is approaching 50TB in one project. Published results include announcement of a test for Alzheimer’s Disease, and identification of the site in the brain where Tinnitus may originate. We hope these results will one day have a significant impact on the health of the general population.
